S5.T1.caption: Table 1: Bias-variance decomposition on the toy regression model. We fix training data, and run each algorithm 100 times from random initializations. We take the average of 100 models as hÂ¯ğœ½subscriptÂ¯â„ğœ½\overline{h}_{\bm{\theta}} in (3). Bias and variance are calculated accordingly. When we increase Kğ¾K from 1 to 40, bias almost remains in the same level, while variance decays at a rate slightly slower than 1K1ğ¾\frac{1}{K}. Variance ceases to decrease after Kğ¾K is larger than 20. This is intuitively understandable as when variance is very low, a larger dataset and number of communication rounds are needed to decrease it further.

K=1(FedAvg) K=2 K=10 K=20 K=40
Bias 0.109 0.117 0.112 0.113 0.112
Variance 0.0496 0.0115 0.0063 0.0045 0.0042
references: We report our predictive results in Table 1 and Fig. 2. Despite the diversity of individual mode predictions (green area), upon averaging, the averaged result becomes more accurate than a fully trained single mode (Fig. 2 (a,b)). Hence, Fed-ensemble is able to average out the noise introduced by individual modes. As a more quantitative measurement, in Table 1 we vary Kğ¾K and calculate the bias-variance decomposition in (3) in each case. As seen in the table, the variance of Fed-ensemble can be efficiently reduced compared with a single mode approach such as FedAvg.

references: We train a 2-layer convolutional neural network to classify different labels. Results in Table 2 show that Fed-ensemble outperforms all benchmarked single mode FL algorithms. This confirms the effectiveness of ensembling over single mode methods in improving generalization. Fedbe turns out to perform closely to single mode algorithms eventually. We conjecture that this happens as the diversity of local models is lost in the knowledge distillation step. To show diversity of models in the ensemble, we plot the the projection of the loss surface on a plane spanned by 3 modes from the ensemble at the end of training in Fig 3. Fig 3 shows that modes (ğ’˜ksubscriptğ’˜ğ‘˜\bm{w}_{k}) have rich diversity: different modes correspond to different local minimum with a high loss barrier on the line connecting them.

We use ResNet [13] for CIFAR, a character-level LSTM model for the sequence prediction task, and ShuffleNet [42] and MobileNet [35] for OpenImage. Results in Table 2 show that Fed-ensemble can indeed improve the generalization performance. Further details on the experimental setup can be found in the Appendix.

S5.T3.caption: Table 3: Sensitivity analysis with different assigned N.o.C on CIFAR-10. Gap denotes the difference in testing accuracy between Fed-ensemble and Fedprox.

N.o.C. Fedavg Fedprox Fed-ensemble Gap

8 85.90 86.06 87.33 1.27
10 86.52 86.77 87.94 1.17
references: We change the number of classes (N.o.C.) assigned to each client from 10 to 2 on the CIFAR-10 dataset. Conceivably, when each client has fewer categories, the data distribution is more variant. The results are shown in Table 3. As expected, the performance of all algorithms degrades with such heterogeneity. Further Fed-ensemble outperforms its counterparts and the performance gap becomes significantly clear as variance increases (i.e., smaller N.o.C.). This highlights the ability of Fed-ensemble to improve generalization specifically with heterogeneous clients.

references:
Since the number of modes, Kğ¾K, in the ensemble is an important hyperparameter, we choose different values of Kğ¾K and test the performance on MNIST. We vary Kğ¾K from 3 to 80. The results are shown in Table 4. Besides testing accuracy of ensemble predictions, we also calculate the accuracy and the entropy of the predictive distribution of each mode in the ensemble.
As shown in Table 4, as Kğ¾K increases from 3 to 40, the ensemble prediction accuracy increases as a result of variance reduction. However, when Kğ¾K is very large, entropy increases and model accuracy drops slightly, suggesting that model prediction is less certain and accurate. The reason here is that when K=80ğ¾80K=80, the number of clients, hence datapoints, assigned to each mode significantly drop. This in turn decreases learning accuracy specifically when datasets are relatively small and a limited budget exists for communication rounds.
